sentences.sentence: Re Pru Goward's opinion piece ("We underestimate the underclass", October 20), I now get the Liberal Party's "lifter-leaner" and "tax recipient-taxpayer" divisive rhetoric.Nowhere in this misguided piece is there any concession that underclass growth is down to the neoliberal agenda imposed since the mid-1970s.Society has been degraded as the bottom half of our population has battled on.
There was a decline in moderately paid manufacturing jobs as tariffs were removed and costs squeezed.
They were automated, outsourced, offshored and casualised.

Making things was replaced with service-based jobs.Agricultural commodity price pressure industrialised agriculture and forced workers to move from the regions, adding to the pool of city poor.Where labour was essential, backpacker slaves were enlisted and wages underpaid.The growing class divide caused a clamour for education and tertiary education, while funding to public schools did not keep up.HECS availability enabled some talented poor kids to escape to university.
Many became exports.Taxation designed for Baby Boomer votes (think negative gearing and capital gains tax concessions) fuelled the ever-increasing price of housing and rents.
The result has been high rents and low housing security for the poor.Migrants suppressed wages and boosted GDP while lowering average GDP per head, leading to inequality.
Economic outcomes led to social outcomes: drugs, alcohol, domestic violence, suicide, youth unemployment.
Every social indicator is getting worse for lower class Australians.Elsewhere this situation has resulted in Brexit and Trumpism.
Fossil fuel and iron ore exports keep Hansonism in check.
Pru Goward does not apparently see any of this.

"Entitlement".Glenn WhiteKelso, QldGoward is spot onwith her analysisI have to congratulate Pru Goward for grappling with a delicate topic.Over the years, I have disagreed with her about a lot of things, but her analysis here of the people who have been left behind, generation after generation, by our ever more unequal society, is very good.She correctly identifies a valuable resource that is being wasted.I would welcome a follow-up with her thoughts about solutions.Gale TreadgoldLindfield, NSWThe fact about state government fundingIn an interview that appeared in the AFR Weekend last Saturday about my book Talk With Your Kids About Things That Matter, I discussed the importance of facts ("The teacher who dumped a law career", October 16-17).But as part of that interview, when the topic turned to school funding, I inadvertently made an error of fact of my own and mistakenly said the state government did not fund independent schools, but that the funding came from federal government sources.In fact, the state government does provide funding as well.

In the interview we discussed how to have big conversations with your kids, and that includes rectifying your errors of fact.Michael ParkerHeadmaster, Newington CollegeRaise the cash rateto a realistic levelThe logical and entirely predictable consequence of the Reserve Bank's cash rate policy over the past two years has come to fruition.The interest rate offered on deposits with the commercial banks has fallen to nearly zero (many banks offer 0.05 per cent) or actually zero.
That's right - some banks offer, for any deposit of $1 or more, the same interest rate you can achieve by stuffing your hard-earned under your mattress.

Moreover, in the latter case, you don't need a card, a PIN, an ATM or a hard-to-find bricks-and-mortar branch office to make a withdrawal - and you don't pay any account fees!The next, predictable step is that deposit rates will go negative - you will have to pay the banks to look after your money and, incomprehensible as it may appear, the banks will pay punters to borrow that money.All because the RBA seems to be, and maybe is, totally divorced from economic and financial reality in maintaining the official cash rate at 0.1 per cent.

Melbourne Cup Day 2021 provides an opportunity for the RBA to get a grip on reality and raise the cash rate - to a minimum of 0.5 per cent - and signal strongly that further increases are in the pipeline.Paul E. BowlerChapman, ACT

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Re Pru Goward's opinion piece ("We underestimate the underclass", October 20), I now get the Liberal Party's "lifter-leaner" and "tax recipient-taxpayer" divisive rhetoric.Nowhere in this misguided piece is there any concession that underclass growth is down to the neoliberal agenda imposed since the mid-1970s.Society has been degraded as the bottom half of our population has battled on. There was a decline in moderately paid manufacturing jobs as tariffs were removed and costs squeezed. They were automated, outsourced, offshored and casualised. Making things was replaced with service-based jobs.Agricultural commodity price pressure industrialised agriculture and forced workers to move from the regions, adding to the pool of city poor.Where labour was essential, backpacker slaves were enlisted and wages underpaid.The growing class divide caused a clamour for education and tertiary education, while funding to public schools did not keep up.HECS availability enabled some talented poor kids to escape to university. Many became exports.Taxation designed for Baby Boomer votes (think negative gearing and capital gains tax concessions) fuelled the ever-increasing price of housing and rents. The result has been high rents and low housing security for the poor.Migrants suppressed wages and boosted GDP while lowering average GDP per head, leading to inequality. Economic outcomes led to social outcomes: drugs, alcohol, domestic violence, suicide, youth unemployment. Every social indicator is getting worse for lower class Australians.Elsewhere this situation has resulted in Brexit and Trumpism. Fossil fuel and iron ore exports keep Hansonism in check. Pru Goward does not apparently see any of this. "Entitlement".Glenn WhiteKelso, QldGoward is spot onwith her analysisI have to congratulate Pru Goward for grappling with a delicate topic.Over the years, I have disagreed with her about a lot of things, but her analysis here of the people who have been left behind, generation after generation, by our ever more unequal society, is very good.She correctly identifies a valuable resource that is being wasted.I would welcome a follow-up with her thoughts about solutions.Gale TreadgoldLindfield, NSWThe fact about state government fundingIn an interview that appeared in the AFR Weekend last Saturday about my book Talk With Your Kids About Things That Matter, I discussed the importance of facts ("The teacher who dumped a law career", October 16-17).But as part of that interview, when the topic turned to school funding, I inadvertently made an error of fact of my own and mistakenly said the state government did not fund independent schools, but that the funding came from federal government sources.In fact, the state government does provide funding as well. In the interview we discussed how to have big conversations with your kids, and that includes rectifying your errors of fact.Michael ParkerHeadmaster, Newington CollegeRaise the cash rateto a realistic levelThe logical and entirely predictable consequence of the Reserve Bank's cash rate policy over the past two years has come to fruition.The interest rate offered on deposits with the commercial banks has fallen to nearly zero (many banks offer 0.05 per cent) or actually zero. That's right - some banks offer, for any deposit of $1 or more, the same interest rate you can achieve by stuffing your hard-earned under your mattress. Moreover, in the latter case, you don't need a card, a PIN, an ATM or a hard-to-find bricks-and-mortar branch office to make a withdrawal - and you don't pay any account fees!The next, predictable step is that deposit rates will go negative - you will have to pay the banks to look after your money and, incomprehensible as it may appear, the banks will pay punters to borrow that money.All because the RBA seems to be, and maybe is, totally divorced from economic and financial reality in maintaining the official cash rate at 0.1 per cent. Melbourne Cup Day 2021 provides an opportunity for the RBA to get a grip on reality and raise the cash rate - to a minimum of 0.5 per cent - and signal strongly that further increases are in the pipeline.Paul E. BowlerChapman, ACT
